I’m really glad you made this video. I work as a research coordinator and help run clinical trials for T Cell therapies, specifically for patients with lung cancers. Patients can go into remission for years on immunotherapy.

I teach anatomy/physiology and I noticed a misleading diagram in this video. It is B-cells that target antigens on pathogens like bacteria and viruses themselves while T-cells identify antigens on the body's own cells who have been infected with a pathogen or become cancerous.

I think the most shocking part wasn't well delivered: those CAR T-cells dont just survive but can seemingly proliferate at a stable level. It's a cure if done well.

Another hot thing I rarely see discussed is how CAR T-cells can be MHC-independent, as their "TCR" is human-made it doesn't need the cancer cell to express MHC-I, which is often downregulated.

Another question the regrowth researchers should answer. What about treating old wounds. After they are done with the first experiment and are satisfied that the treated frogs have grown as much of a leg as they can, take half the control group and amputate just a little further up their leg, creating a new wound. Then apply the drug/dome treatment, and see if they regrow anything.

Folks who are already amputees will be very interested in knowing if this kind of treatment will work on old amputations.

Additionally, it would be interesting to see if "smaller" amputations get better results. For example, does a toe fully grow where a full leg only regrows a leg like structure?

When you use carT therapy to kill cancer you can’t control the rate of cytokine release from the destroyed cancer cells, it results in a positive feedback loop, since cytokines then signal other T-cells. In most animal models the cytokine storm  and pyrogens would cause the little rats to cook from there own body heat. But I guess if it’s dosed low enough that doesn’t happen ?

Cancer cells aren't expert at any thing. T cells don't react to them because they're the host's own cells. There would have to be enough generic damage to produce proteins that would bind to T cells. If T cells reacted to them without that level of damage, they'd attack the host's own healthy cells, e.g. lupus or multiple sclerosis.

It's a a bit annoying to talk about chemical reactions as if they were imbued with some form of sentience.

Let's address the elephant in the room :

Immune therapy is not widely used because it lacks a very crucial step that the (internal) immune system has - the same one that makes immune response to cancer so difficult - attacking cancer cells but not host cells.
Teaching T cells a tiny bit wrong means they start attacking healthy cells, resulting in what is known as cytokine storm , which leads to death in hours if not treated, and often severe organ damage and finger/toe amputation even if treated successfully. And if malicious t-cells are not cleared out, the person now has to constantly suppress their own immune system. Which then quickly gets overwhelmed by still-active cancer.

Was this problem addressed somehow or not?
Otherwise use of such therapy is quite niche and rather risky.

Even if all goes well, cytokine storm may still occur if a lot of cancer cells are present (and there are usually more than enough) when the immune system realized it has an organ-sized amount of pathogenic tissue. This is called Cytokine release syndrome and usually requires the immune system to be suppressed at least somewhat which allows the cancer to adapt while immune system is working but severely weakened. This is one of the reasons for doubts in long-term effects.
